reason.tex:
%text Ordinarily, we expect curves to be of the form $y = f(x)$
But if both $x$ and $y$ are expressed in terms of a third variable/parameter, then we have what is called a \underline\text{parametric curve}
Instead of one $y = f(x)$ type equation, we will have two equations in terms of the parameter $(t)$
\[ \quad x = f(t) \text{ and } y = g(t) \]
\underline\text{The curve is still plotted in $x-y} It is only expressed in terms of $t$
\underline\text{Coordinates of a point $A$} A point $A$ on the curve will have the coordinates \[ \qquad A = (x,y) = \left(f(t), g(t) \right)\]
\underline\text{Slope of the tangent at $A$} The slope of the tangent will continue to be $\frac{dy}{dx}$. However,
\[ \quad \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \frac{dy / dt}{dx / dt}\]
